entry.title: Ëã±ËØ≠ÂÜô‰Ωú
entry.content: Euphemism (ÂßîÂ©âËØ≠) an inoffensive expression that is substituted for one that is considered offensive e.g.: You are well fed. (You are fat) ‚Äã We have to let you go (You are fired.) Hyperbole (Â§∏Âº†) The use of exaggerated terms for the purpose of emphasis or heightened effect. e.g.: When she heard the bad news, a river of tears poured out. Irony (ËÆΩÂà∫) The use of words to convey the opposite of their literal meaning. e.g.: It would be a fine thing indeed not knowing what time it was in the morning. This hard-working boy seldom reads more than an hour per week. Metaphor An implied comparison between two unlike things that actually have sth important in common. ‚Äã e.g.: The sofa is fertile soil for a couch potato. Simile A stated comparison (usually formed with ‚Äúlike‚Äù or ‚Äúas‚Äù) between two fundamentally dissimilar things that have qualities in common. e.g.: She looks like a flower but stings like a bee. metonymy A figure of speech in which one word or phrase is substituted for another with which it is closely related. (describing sth indirectly by referring to things around it) e.g.: He writes a fine hand. (he has good hand writing.) Synecdoche A figure of speech in which a part is used for the whole (as hand for sailor), the whole for a part (as the law for police officer), the specific for the general (as cutthroat for assassin), the general for the specific (as thief for pickpocket), or the material for the thing from which it is made (as steel for sword ). e.g.: ABCs (alphabet) e.g.: England won the World Cup in 1966. (Football team of England) Personification A figure of speech in which an inanimate object is endowed with human qualities or abilities. e.g.: The carved pumpkin smiled at me. Bias a partiality that prevents objective consideration of an issue or situation. It ia usually neutral. Prejudice a partiality that prevents objective consideration of an issue or situation.It ususally have negative meaning. Context discourse that surrounds a language unit and helps to determine its interpretation. Objective based on facts, or making a decision that is based on facts rather than on your feelings or beliefs Sujective a statement, report, attitude etc is influenced by personal opinion and can therefore be unfair. Thesis Statement A thesis statement usually appears near the end of the introductory paragraph of a paper, and it offers a concise summary of the main point or claim of the essay, research paper, etc. Point of view a particular way of thinking about or judging a situation ËßÜËßíÔºåËßíÂ∫¶ Emotive characterized by emotion Factual based on facts or relating to facts Critical thinking Conclusion something you decide after considering all the information you have Fiction a literary work based on the imagination and not necessarily on fact Revision Topics ‚Äì Reading and Writing Course Examination, Summer 2018 The materials here are designed to help you with the examination. Not all of the things included here will appear on the examination, but you need to be prepared just in case. Exam Format Section A ‚Äì Mainly factual recall and understanding questions on key terms from this semester (35%) Section B ‚Äì Multiple Choice (20%) Section C ‚Äì Reading comprehension: extended writing (15%) Section D ‚Äì Extended writing (30%) Critical Thinking ‚Äì Possible Questions What is critical thinking? An effective, logical approach to academic work. It encourages students to reflect on what they learn. critical thinking is defined as: ‚Äúthe process of actively and skillfully conceptualizing, applying, analyzing, and evaluating information to reach an answer or conclusion Name four skills you associate with critical thinking. analysis questioning indepentent learning ‚Äã applying How does critical thinking improve a person‚Äôs quality of reading (or writing, or both)? Encourages analysis and questioning of texts. Helps us detect bias, prejudice, inaccuracies, limitations or contradictions. Facilitates independent learning. How can critical thinking help students? Helps students distinguish between what is essential, what is possibly useful and what is probably irrelevant. The wording of the question and number of marks should act as a guide as to how much detail to include. Briefly Describe Three Elements of Critical Thinking It encourages individuals to analyse and ask questions rather than just accept things at face value. It helps individuals to identify bias or prejudice and to formulate arguments based on evidence. It helps individuals to understand the importance of historical and social context to topics studied. There are others. As this says ‚Äòdescribe‚Äô some detail is needed, but a 12 mark question requires much more. Features of Academic Writing Structure ‚Äì introduction, body paragraphs (or main body), and conclusion. There should be a logical sequence. Purpose ‚Äì can include inform, explain, compare and contrast, justify, analyse etc. Style ‚Äì should be impersonal, objective, well-reasoned, and based upon carefully selected evidence. It includes careful analysis and critical thinking. Features of Academic Writing Possible Questions What should you include in an introduction? Some backgroud information and the thesis statement. What is a thesis statement? ‚Äã A thesis statement usually appears near the end of the introductory paragraph of a paper, and it offers a concise summary of the main point or claim of the AW. Explain five different ways of supporting a point you are making in an academic essay. Using group of three Using statistics and data Using quotations Using examples Using questions, shock tactics Why are quotations useful in academic writing? It‚Äôs experts‚Äô opinions and readers will believe what you are saying is true. Why do you include footnotes and a bibliography? To avoid plagiarism What should you include in a conclusion? a position or opinion or judgment reached after consideration Context Basically the what, where? when? who? how? and why? that readers need to know. Context helps the reader understand cultural, social, economic, political, philosophical and religious ideas. Some of the main things that affect context are time period, gender, race, religion, social, class, author‚Äôs purpose and bias etc. Context varies according to situation/type of writing etc. Example of Context Any academic essay you have written this semester: ‚Äã Any work of literature, eg Romeo and Juliet The context might include what the task or question, what was being assessed (purpose), the number of words, the research you needed to do, the skills you were expected to demonstrate etc. What else? The author and the time it was written are very important (reflect contemporary attitudes); a play (tragedy); why it was written (intended to be performed rather than read); key themes explored etc. Bias A one-sided view or account of a situation.a partiality that prevents objective consideration of an issue or situation. Seeks to pass opinion of as fact; often unsupported or based on flawed/twisted logic. It may reveal the author‚Äôs preferences or prejudices. It may be deliberate or accidental, subtle or blatant, conscious or sub-conscious. Politicians use biased language to attack their rivals. Other examples? ‚Äã trademen use bias language to sell goods. Bias You may need to define bias and/or identify different types of bias. You may encounter bias in a reading text. You may have to change a sentence to make it biased, or make a biased sentence more objective. You may have to write in a biased style. Perspective The writer‚Äôs perspective can be an important element of context, as can the reader‚Äôs. An individual‚Äôs perspective is shaped by the time period; their social class; their age and gender; family influence; political, religious, social and cultural issues etc. A person‚Äôs perspective might reveal their bias. A person‚Äôs perspective often helps us understand motive. Different Types of Language Subjective Personal Biased Emotive Judgmental Manipulative Extreme Objective Impersonal Unbiased Neutral Analytical Balanced Measured Which of these do you associate with academic writing? Anything else? Second group. Based upon carefully selected evidence. Plagiarism Possible Questions What is it? Plagiarism means copying work from another source such as textbook or an article online and presented as being your own work. It may be a few lines, a couple of paragraphs or a whole section. Why is it considered a problem in academic writing? It is a form of intellectual property theft in academic writing. It is cheating. Why is it so widespread? Because Students do not know enough about the importance of Academic writing and online resources are easily gained. How can plagiarism be avoided? (eg Explain two ways ‚Ä¶..) Use quotation marks whenever quoting an exact phrase, sentence or short paragraph Make sure you acknowledged and cited all sources of borrowed ideas and materials. Is plagiarism always a bad thing? No,sometimes make reference to others‚Äò opinion can widen our horizonÔºåbut can‚Äôt totally use others‚Äô opinion and represent it as our own. Language You should be able to identify and give examples of different types of figurative language. You should know the difference between a simile and a metaphor. You should be able to identify and use techniques like groups of three. ‚Äã This solution is simple, easy and comprehensive You should understand the function of rhetorical questions. A rhetorical question can lay emphasis on some point being discussed, when no real answer is expected Part Three Read the text and the question carefully. Use quotations to support the arguments you put forward and make sure you link them to the question. Include critical thinking ‚Äì do not just accept what you are told at face value. Is it honest, accurate, reliable, logical etc? Make sure you write enough. Check your writing at the end to avoid silly mistakes. Part Four Here you will have to argue something. It will not be something you have looked at in class. Try to put forward views in support of and against the issue or quotation, but come down on one side. Include as many references as you can to recent events, history, literature, personal experience etc as you can to support your arguments. Use appropriate language and structure. Follow instructions carefully. Vary your Vocabulary What is the relationship between capability and responsibility? the quality of being capable to do sth . ‚Äì physically or intellectually or legally a duty to deal with or take care of sb/sth, so that you may be blamed if sth goes wrong This was the basis of a question in a recent writing competition. Write down as many different ways of expressing the ideas ‚Äòcapability‚Äô and ‚Äòresponsibility‚Äô as you can. Vary Your Vocabulary Capability Responsibility Ability Talent Skill(s) Knowledge Proficiency Qualifications Duty/duties Leadership Management Goals/objectives Experience Choose Different Ways of Expressing these Terms Inequality Wealth Happiness Success Intelligence Advantage Disadvantage Violence Integrity Communication Knowledge Ambition Power Poverty Progress Education Conflict Rivalry Identify, and if necessary, explain what you understand by key terms in the question. Context to Quotations If you are given a quotation by a particular author, scientist or other famous individual, that is an important part of the context. Why might he/she hold this view? Do you agree with it? Think of reasons for/against. If it is a historical figure, does his/her ‚Äòwisdom‚Äô still apply today? Is the quotation serious or not? Possible sources might include Shakespeare, Voltaire, Napoleon, Einstein, Confucius. Who else? Summing Up You will definitely need to know about these in the examination: Context Bias Perspective Plagiarism Critical Thinking

entry.title: RelationShip2
entry.content: ÊàëÊúâ‰∏Ä‰∏™Áî∑ÊúãÂèãÔºå‰ªñÂßìÂº† Âº†Êüê‰∫∫ÁªôÊàëÁöÑÁîúËúú ÂÉèÁ≥ñÂä†Â§ö‰∫ÜÁöÑÂç°Â∏ÉÂ•áËØ∫ÂÉèÂêêÈ≤ÅÁï™ÂàöÂàáÂºÄ‰∏ÄÂçäÁöÑË•øÁìúÁöÑÁ¨¨‰∏ÄÂè£ÂÉèÈò≥ÂÖâÊôíÂ§öÁöÑÂ±±Á´πÊ±ÅÂÉèËΩØÂïæÂïæÁöÑÊ£âËä±Á≥ñ Âº†Êüê‰∫∫ÂæàÂÆ†ÊàëËôΩÁÑ∂ÊàëÂè£Â§¥‰∏äËÄÅÊòØËØ¥‰ªñ‰∏çÂÆ†ÊàëÂÖ∂ÂÆû‰πüÂè™ÊòØ‰∏∫‰∫ÜÁúã‰ªñÈú≤Âá∫‰∏ÄËÑ∏Êó†Â•àÂèàÂÆ†Ê∫∫ ‰∏çÂøçÂøÉËØ¥ÊïôÊàëÁöÑÁ•ûÊÉÖÁÑ∂ÂêéÊöóËá™ÂæóÊÑè üòç Êàë‰πüÂæàÂÆ†Âº†Êüê‰∫∫ÊØîÂ¶ÇÊàë‰π∞ÁöÑÈõ∂È£üÈÉΩ‰ºöÂàÜ‰ªñ‰∏âÂàÜ‰πã‰∫åÊÇÑÊÇÑÁªô‰ªñÂáÜÂ§á‰∏ÄÂ§ßÊ≥¢‰∫åÂçÅÂ≤ÅÁîüÊó•ÊÉäÂñú‰ºöÂ∏¶‰ªñÂéªÁúãÊúÄËøëÁà±ÁúãÁöÑÂ∞èËØ¥ÁöÑËàûÂè∞Ââß Âú®Âº†Êüê‰∫∫Ë∫´‰∏ä ÊàëÊòéÁôΩ‰∫ÜÂÖ∂ÂÆûÂñúÊ¨¢ ÁúüÁöÑÂèØ‰ª•Âè™ÊòØ‰∏ÄÁû¨Èó¥ÁöÑ‰∫ãÊÉÖ Âπ¥Â∞ëÈùû‰∏ªÊµÅÁöÑÊàë ÂñúÊ¨¢Áî®Á©∫Èó¥ÁïôË®ÄÊùøËÆ∞ÂΩïÁîüÊ¥ª‰∫éÊòØÊúâ‰∫ÜËøôÊ†∑‰∏ÄÊÆµÂºÄÂßãÂñúÊ¨¢Âº†Êüê‰∫∫ÁöÑËÆ∞ÂΩï Âú®‰∏âÊúàÊüê‰∏™Â§©Ê∞îÂØíÂÜ∑ÁöÑÂ§úÊôöÊàëÂÆûÂú®ÊÉ≥‰∏çÂá∫‰ªÄ‰πàÁêÜÁî±ÊääÂº†Êüê‰∫∫Âè´Âá∫Êù•ÁÑ∂ÂêéÊàëÁúãÂà∞‰∫ÜÊàëÁöÑÈí±ÂåÖ ÊòØÁöÑÔºåÊàëÂèëÂæÆ‰ø°ËÆ©Âº†Êüê‰∫∫Èô™ÊàëÂéªÈì∂Ë°åÂ≠òÈí±Êôö‰∏äÂçÅÁÇπ Ê∏©Â∫¶ÂçÅÂ∫¶ ÊêûÁ¨ëÁöÑÊòØ‰∏ÄËøûÂéª‰∫Ü‰∏§ÂÆ∂Èì∂Ë°å‰∏ÄÂÆ∂Â≠ò‰∏ç‰∫Ü ‰∏ÄÂÆ∂Â§ñÈÉ®Ë£Ö‰øÆÂ∑≤ÁªèÂÖ≥Èó®ÊâÄ‰ª•Êàë‰ª¨‰ø©Âï•ÈÉΩÊ≤°Âπ≤ ÂèàËµ∞‰∫ÜÂõûÊù• ÂõûÊù•ÁöÑË∑Ø‰∏äÔºåÊàëË∂äÊÉ≥Ë∂äËßâÂæóÂ§™‰∏çÂÄº‰∫ÜÂá∫Êù•‰∏ÄË∂üÂï•Êî∂Ëé∑ÈÉΩÊ≤°ÊúâÂ§©Ê∞îÊúâÁÇπÂÜ∑ Âº†Êüê‰∫∫ËæπËµ∞ËæπÊääÊâãÊè£Âú®ÂÖúÈáåÊàëÈóÆ‰ªñ ‰Ω†ÂÜ∑‰∏çÂÜ∑ÂëÄÔºü‰ªñËØ¥Ôºö‰∏çÂÜ∑ÊàëËØ¥ÔºöÊàëÂÜ∑ÁÑ∂ÂêéÊääÊâãÊîæËøõ‰∫Ü‰ªñÂÖúÈáåÁöÑÊâãÈáå Â∞±Ëøô‰πà‰∏ÄÁõ¥ÁâµÁùÄËµ∞ÁùÄÊàëÁ™ÅÁÑ∂ËßâÂæóÊúâÁÇπ‰∏çÂØπÂä≤ÊàëÔºöÂº†CÂº†Êüê‰∫∫ÔºöÊÄé‰πà‰∫ÜÔºüÊàëÔºö‰Ω†Â•ΩÂÉèÈ°∫Êãê‰∫Ü ÈÇ£ÊôöÁöÑÊÑüÊÉ≥‚¨á ‰∏äÊ¨°ËØ¥Âà∞ÊàëÁîüÊó•‰ªñÁªôÊàë‰π∞‰∫Ü‰∏ÄÊîØÂè£Á∫¢üíÑÁªìÊûúÊúâ‰∏ÄÊ¨°‰∏çÂ∞èÂøÉË¢´ÊàëÂºÑ‰∏¢‰∫ÜÊàëÈöæËøá‰∫ÜÂ•Ω‰πÖÂáÜÂ§áËá™Â∑±ÂÅ∑ÂÅ∑‰π∞‰∏ÄÂè™‰∏ÄÊ†∑ÁöÑ‰πü‰∏ÄÁõ¥Ê≤°ÊúâÂëäËØâ‰ªñ ‰ΩÜÊòØÂêéÊù•Â•ΩÊúãÂèãÂäùÊàëÂèëÊúãÂèãÂúàÊàëÊÉ≥‰∫ÜÊÉ≥ ÂÜç‰π∞Â§öÂ∞ëÊîØ‰πü‰∏çÊòØÂéüÊù•ÈÇ£ÊîØ‰ªñÈÄÅÊàëÁöÑ‰∫ÜÊâÄ‰ª•ÂÜ≥ÂÆöÂëäËØâ‰ªñ Ë∞ÉÁöÆÁöÑÊàë‚¨á ÂêéÊù•ÊàëÊâæÂà∞‰∫Ü‚¨á Êàë‰∏çÂñúÊ¨¢Ëøô‰∏ñÁïåÊàëÂè™ÂñúÊ¨¢‰Ω†

entry.title: Post new article
entry.content: Â¶Ç‰ΩïÁî®blogÂèëÂ∏ÉÊñáÁ´†ÁöÑÊïôÁ®ã 1.ÂÜôÊñáÁ´†ÔºöÂú®hexoÊâÄÂú®ÁõÆÂΩï‰∏ãÔºåÊâìÂºÄterminalÔºåÂú®ÂëΩ‰ª§Ë°åËæìÂÖ•Ôºöhexo new a aÊòØÊñáÁ´†Ê†áÈ¢òÔºå‰πüÂèØ‰ª•Âä†‰∏äÂèåÂºïÂè∑,Â¶Ç‚Äúa‚Äù_postsÈáåÁúãËßÅÂ§ö‰∫Ü‰∏Ä‰∏™a.mdÊñá‰ª∂„ÄÇÂõ†Ê≠§Êàë‰ª¨‰πüÁü•ÈÅì‰∫ÜÔºåÈªòËÆ§ÊÉÖÂÜµ‰∏ãÔºåhexo‰∏∫Êàë‰ª¨ÂàõÂª∫ÁöÑÊòØmarkdownÊñá‰ª∂„ÄÇÂà∑Êñ∞È°µÈù¢Ôºàhttp://localhost:4000/ÔºâÊàë‰ª¨ËÉΩÁúãËßÅÊñ∞Ê∑ª‰∏Ä‰∏™ÂêçÂ≠óÂè´aÁöÑÊñáÁ´†ÔºåÊ≤°Êúâ‰ªª‰ΩïÂÜÖÂÆπ„ÄÇËÄåËøô‰∏™_postsÊñá‰ª∂Â§πÔºåÁÆóÊòØ‰∏Ä‰∏™ÊØîËæÉÁâπÊÆäÁöÑÊñá‰ª∂Â§πÔºåÂõ†‰∏∫ÂÆÉË£ÖÁùÄÊâÄÊúâ‰Ω†ÂèëÂ∏ÉÂá∫ÂéªÁöÑÊñáÁ´†„ÄÇ 2.ËçâÁ®øÁÆ±‰∏ä‰∏ÄÊ≠•Êàë‰ª¨Êñ∞Âª∫Âá∫Êù•ÁöÑÔºåÂè´ÂÅöpost page„ÄÇÈô§‰∫Üpost pageÔºåÊàë‰ª¨ËøòÂèØ‰ª•Êñ∞Âª∫draft pageÔºå‰πüÂ∞±ÊòØËçâÁ®ø„ÄÇÂæàÂ§öÊó∂ÂÄôÊàë‰ª¨ÈúÄË¶ÅÂÖàÂÜôÊàêËçâÁ®øÔºåËÄåÊöÇÊó∂‰∏çÂèëÂ∏ÉÂá∫Âéª„ÄÇdraft pageÂ∞±ÂèØ‰ª•Êª°Ë∂≥Êàë‰ª¨ÁöÑË¶ÅÊ±ÇÔºåÊàë‰ª¨ÁöÑÁΩëÁ´ô‰∏äÊòØÁúã‰∏çÂà∞ËçâÁ®øÊñá‰ª∂ÁöÑ„ÄÇÂú®terminalËæìÂÖ•hexo new draft bÊàë‰ª¨‰ºöÂú®source‰∏ãÁúãËßÅ‰∏Ä‰∏™Êñ∞ÁöÑÊñá‰ª∂Â§πÔºå_draftsÔºåËøô‰∏™ÈáåÈù¢‰ºöË£ÖÊàë‰ª¨ÊâÄÊúâÁöÑËçâÁ®øÊñá‰ª∂„ÄÇÈÇ£ÂÜôÂ•Ω‰∫ÜÁöÑËçâÁ®øÔºåÂ¶Ç‰ΩïÂèØ‰ª•Âú®‰∏çÂèëÂ∏ÉÁöÑÊÉÖÂÜµ‰∏ãÔºåÈ¢ÑËßà‰∏Ä‰∏ãÊñáÁ´†Âú®ÁΩëÁ´ô‰∏äÁöÑÊ†∑Â≠êÂë¢Ôºühexo server ‚ÄìdraftÂΩìÁÑ∂Ôºå‰Ω†Ë¶ÅÂÖàshut downÂéüÊù•ÂºÄÁùÄÈÇ£‰∏™serverÔºåÊâçÂèØ‰ª•ÂºÄÂêØÊñ∞ÁöÑserver„ÄÇÂ¶ÇÊ≠§‰∏ÄÊù•ÔºåÊàë‰ª¨Â∞±ÂèØ‰ª•È¢ÑËßàËçâÁ®øÊñá‰ª∂Âï¶ 3: ÂèëÂ∏ÉËçâÁ®øÂΩì‰Ω†ÂáÜÂ§áÂ•Ω‰∫ÜË¶ÅÂèëÂ∏ÉËçâÁ®øÊó∂:hexo publish b‰Ω†‰ºöÂèëÁé∞_draftsÈáåÁöÑb.md‰∏çËßÅ‰∫ÜÔºåË∑ëÂà∞‰∫Ü_postsÈáåÈù¢,‰πüÂ∞±ËØ¥Êòé‰Ω†ÁöÑËçâÁ®øÂèëÂ∏ÉÊàêÂäü‰∫Ü„ÄÇ 4: normal pageÊàëÁõÆÂâçËøò‰∏çÁü•ÈÅìËØ•Â¶Ç‰ΩïÁî®‰∏≠ÊñáÁß∞ÂëºËøôÁ±ªÈ°µÈù¢„ÄÇÊàë‰ª¨ÂèØ‰ª•ÊääpostÂíådraftÁªüÁß∞‰∏∫blog pagesÔºåÂú®Ëøô‰πãÂ§ñÁöÑ‰∏ÄÁßçÂ∞±ÊòØnormal pagesÔºå Á±ª‰ºº‰∏Ä‰∏™ÁΩëÁ´ô‰∏äÁöÑ‚ÄúÂÖ≥‰∫é‚ÄùÔºå‚Äú‰∫ÜËß£Êàë‰ª¨‚Äù‰πãÁ±ªÁöÑÈ°µÈù¢„ÄÇËøôÁ±ªpageË¶ÅÂ¶Ç‰ΩïÊñ∞Âª∫Âë¢Ôºühexo new page cÂíåÂâç‰∏§Áßç‰∏çÂêåÔºåËøô‰∏™ÂëΩ‰ª§‰ºöÂú®sourceÊñá‰ª∂Â§πÂÜÖÂàõÂª∫Âá∫cÊñá‰ª∂Â§πÔºå‰∏é_postsÔºå_draftsÂπ∂Âàó„ÄÇÊñá‰ª∂Â§πÈáåÈù¢Êúâ‰∏Ä‰∏™index.mdÊñá‰ª∂„ÄÇÂà∑Êñ∞È°µÈù¢Ôºå‰Ω†‰ºöÂèëÁé∞cÂπ∂Ê≤°ÊúâÂá∫Áé∞Âú®È°µÈù¢ÂÜÖÔºåÈÇ£ÂÆÉÂú®Âì™ÂÑøÂë¢ÔºüÂú®ÁΩëÂùÄÂêéÈù¢Âä†‰∏äc/Ôºå Âç≥http://localhost:4000/c/ÔºåÂ∞±ÂèØ‰ª•ÁúãÂà∞‰∫Ü„ÄÇÊ≠£Âõ†‰∏∫c‰∏çÊòØ‰∏Ä‰∏™blog pageÔºåÊâÄ‰ª•ÂÆÉ‰πü‰∏ç‰ºöÂá∫Áé∞Âú®blogÂàóË°®‰∏≠ÔºåËÄåÊòØË¶ÅÈÄöËøáURLÂéªaccess„ÄÇStep 5: ‰∏Ä‰∏™Â∞ètipÁé∞Âú®Êàë‰ª¨‰∫ÜËß£Âà∞page‰∏ÄÂÖ±Êúâ‰∏âÁßçÔºåpostÔºådraftÔºånormal„ÄÇ page_layout.pngÈÇ£‰∏∫‰ªÄ‰πà‰∏ÄÂºÄÂßãÁöÑÊó∂ÂÄôÊàë‰ª¨Áî®hexo new aÂ∞±Áõ¥Êé•ÁîüÊàê‰∫Üpost pageÂë¢ÔºüÂõ†‰∏∫ÈªòËÆ§ÁöÑËÆæÁΩÆ„ÄÇÊâìÂºÄÁÜüÊÇâÁöÑ_config.ymlÊñá‰ª∂ÔºåÊâæÂà∞default_layout: postËøôÂè•Ë°®Á§∫ÈªòËÆ§ÁöÑÈ°µÈù¢‰ºöÊñ∞Âª∫ÊàêpostÊ†ºÂºèÁöÑ„ÄÇÊâÄ‰ª•ÔºåÂ¶ÇÊûú‰Ω†‰π†ÊÉØÂÖàÊääÊñáÁ´†ÂÜôÊàêËçâÁ®øÔºåÈÇ£Â∞±ÊääÂÆÉÊîπÊàêdraftÂ∞±Â•Ω„ÄÇ

entry.title: Hello World
entry.content: Welcome to Hexo! This is your very first post. Check documentation for more info. If you get any problems when using Hexo, you can find the answer in troubleshooting or you can ask me on GitHub. Quick StartCreate a new post1$ hexo new "My New Post" More info: Writing Run server1$ hexo server More info: Server Generate static files1$ hexo generate More info: Generating Deploy to remote sites1$ hexo deploy More info: Deployment
